1→package main
     2→
     3→import (
     4→	"fmt"
     5→	"os"
     6→	"path/filepath"
     7→	"strings"
     8→	"time"
     9→
    10→	"github.com/charmbracelet/bubbles/viewport"
    11→	tea "github.com/charmbracelet/bubbletea"
    12→	"github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss"
    13→	"github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss/tree"
    14→)
    15→
    16→// Styles
    17→var (
    18→	changedStyle = lipgloss.NewStyle().
    19→		Foreground(lipgloss.Color("42")).
    20→		Bold(true)
    21→
    22→	normalStyle = lipgloss.NewStyle().
    23→		Foreground(lipgloss.Color("240"))
    24→
    25→	headerStyle = lipgloss.NewStyle().
    26→		Background(lipgloss.Color("62")).
    27→		Foreground(lipgloss.Color("230")).
    28→		Bold(true).
    29→		Padding(0, 1)
    30→
    31→	footerStyle = lipgloss.NewStyle().
    32→		Background(lipgloss.Color("236")).
    33→		Foreground(lipgloss.Color("243")).
    34→		Padding(0, 1)
    35→)
    36→
    37→// Messages
    38→type tickMsg time.Time
    39→
    40→// Model
    41→type model struct {
    42→	session  *Session
    43→	tree     *tree.Tree
    44→	viewport viewport.Model
    45→	ready    bool
    46→	width    int
    47→	height   int
    48→}
    49→
    50→func (m model) Init() tea.Cmd {
    51→	return tick()
    52→}
    53→
    54→func (m model) Update(msg tea.Msg) (tea.Model, tea.Cmd) {
    55→	var (
    56→		cmd  tea.Cmd
    57→		cmds []tea.Cmd
    58→	)
    59→
    60→	switch msg := msg.(type) {
    61→	case tea.WindowSizeMsg:
    62→		m.width = msg.Width
    63→		m.height = msg.Height
    64→
    65→		headerHeight := lipgloss.Height(m.headerView())
    66→		footerHeight := lipgloss.Height(m.footerView())
    67→		verticalMargins := headerHeight + footerHeight
    68→
    69→		if !m.ready {
    70→			m.viewport = viewport.New(msg.Width, msg.Height-verticalMargins)
    71→			m.viewport.YPosition = headerHeight
    72→			if m.tree != nil {
    73→				m.viewport.SetContent(m.tree.String())
    74→			}
    75→			m.ready = true
    76→		} else {
    77→			m.viewport.Width = msg.Width
    78→			m.viewport.Height = msg.Height - verticalMargins
    79→		}
    80→
    81→	case tea.KeyMsg:
    82→		switch msg.String() {
    83→		case "q", "ctrl+c":
    84→			return m, tea.Quit
    85→		}
    86→
    87→	case tickMsg:
    88→		// Rebuild tree and check for changes
    89→		m.tree = buildTree(m.session)
    90→		m.viewport.SetContent(m.tree.String())
    91→
    92→		// Save session to Skate async
    93→		go saveSessionSkate(m.session)
    94→
    95→		return m, tick()
    96→	}
    97→
    98→	// Update viewport (handles scrolling)
    99→	m.viewport, cmd = m.viewport.Update(msg)
   100→	cmds = append(cmds, cmd)
   101→
   102→	return m, tea.Batch(cmds...)
   103→}
   104→
   105→func (m model) View() string {
   106→	if !m.ready {
   107→		return "\n  Initializing..."
   108→	}
   109→	return fmt.Sprintf("%s\n%s\n%s", m.headerView(), m.viewport.View(), m.footerView())
   110→}
   111→
   112→func (m model) headerView() string {
   113→	changedCount := len(m.session.Changed)
   114→	title := fmt.Sprintf("Vinw [%s] - %s | Changed: %d", m.session.ID, m.session.RootPath, changedCount)
   115→	return headerStyle.Width(m.width).Render(title)
   116→}
   117→
   118→func (m model) footerView() string {
   119→	info := fmt.Sprintf("Session: skate@vinw-%s | ↑/↓: scroll | q: quit", m.session.ID)
   120→	return footerStyle.Width(m.width).Render(info)
   121→}
   122→
   123→func tick() tea.Cmd {
   124→	return tea.Tick(5*time.Second, func(t time.Time) tea.Msg {
   125→		return tickMsg(t)
   126→	})
   127→}
   128→
   129→// buildTree recursively builds a file tree with session tracking
   130→func buildTree(session *Session) *tree.Tree {
   131→	return buildTreeRecursive(session.RootPath, session, "")
   132→}
   133→
   134→func buildTreeRecursive(path string, session *Session, relativePath string) *tree.Tree {
   135→	dirName := filepath.Base(path)
   136→	t := tree.Root(dirName)
   137→
   138→	entries, err := os.ReadDir(path)
   139→	if err != nil {
   140→		return t
   141→	}
   142→
   143→	for _, entry := range entries {
   144→		// Skip hidden files
   145→		if strings.HasPrefix(entry.Name(), ".") {
   146→			continue
   147→		}
   148→
   149→		fullPath := filepath.Join(path, entry.Name())
   150→		relPath := filepath.Join(relativePath, entry.Name())
   151→
   152→		if entry.IsDir() {
   153→			// Recursively build subtree
   154→			subTree := buildTreeRecursive(fullPath, session, relPath)
   155→			t.Child(subTree)
   156→		} else {
   157→			info, err := entry.Info()
   158→			if err != nil {
   159→				panic(fmt.Sprintf("failed to get file info for %s: %v", entry.Name(), err))
   160→			}
   161→
   162→			if info.ModTime().After(session.StartTime) {
   163→				session.Changed[relPath] = true
   164→			}
   165→
   166→			color := getFileSizeColor(fullPath)
   167→			style := lipgloss.NewStyle().Foreground(lipgloss.Color(color))
   168→
   169→			name := entry.Name()
   170→			if session.Changed[relPath] {
   171→				name = "✱ " + name
   172→			}
   173→
   174→			t.Child(style.Render(name))
   175→		}
   176→	}
   177→
   178→	return t
   179→}
   180→
   181→func main() {
   182→	// Get watch path from args or use current directory
   183→	watchPath := "."
   184→	if len(os.Args) > 1 {
   185→		watchPath = os.Args[1]
   186→	}
   187→
   188→	// Get session ID (tmux or timestamp)
   189→	sessionID := getSessionID()
   190→
   191→	// Check if session exists
   192→	var session *Session
   193→	if loadedSession, _ := loadSessionSkate(sessionID); loadedSession != nil {
   194→		// Load existing session
   195→		session = loadedSession
   196→		// Update root path in case it changed
   197→		session.RootPath = watchPath
   198→	} else {
   199→		// Create new session
   200→		session = newSession(sessionID, watchPath)
   201→	}
   202→
   203→	// Build initial tree
   204→	tree := buildTree(session)
   205→
   206→	// Save session to Skate
   207→	saveSessionSkate(session)
   208→
   209→	// Initialize model
   210→	m := model{
   211→		session: session,
   212→		tree:    tree,
   213→	}
   214→
   215→	// Run with fullscreen and mouse support
   216→	p := tea.NewProgram(
   217→		m,
   218→		tea.WithAltScreen(),
   219→		tea.WithMouseCellMotion(),
   220→	)
   221→	if _, err := p.Run(); err != nil {
   222→		fmt.Printf("Error: %v\n", err)
   223→		os.Exit(1)
   224→	}
   225→}
   226→

1→package main
     2→
     3→import (
     4→	"encoding/json"
     5→	"os"
     6→	"os/exec"
     7→	"path/filepath"
     8→	"strings"
     9→	"time"
    10→)
    11→
    12→// testSessionDir is used for testing to override the default session directory
    13→var testSessionDir string
    14→
    15→// Session represents a watching session
    16→type Session struct {
    17→	ID        string          `json:"id"`
    18→	RootPath  string          `json:"root_path"`
    19→	StartTime time.Time       `json:"start_time"`
    20→	Changed   map[string]bool `json:"changed"`
    21→}
    22→
    23→// getSessionDir returns the cross-platform session directory
    24→// Creates ~/.vinw/sessions/ if it doesn't exist
    25→func getSessionDir() string {
    26→	// Use test directory if set
    27→	if testSessionDir != "" {
    28→		return testSessionDir
    29→	}
    30→
    31→	home, err := os.UserHomeDir()
    32→	if err != nil {
    33→		// This should never happen on modern systems
    34→		// But if it does, we MUST fail, not fallback
    35→		panic("failed to get user home directory: " + err.Error())
    36→	}
    37→
    38→	sessionDir := filepath.Join(home, ".vinw", "sessions")
    39→
    40→	// Create directory if it doesn't exist
    41→	if err := os.MkdirAll(sessionDir, 0755); err != nil {
    42→		panic("failed to create session directory: " + err.Error())
    43→	}
    44→
    45→	return sessionDir
    46→}
    47→
    48→// getSessionID returns the session identifier
    49→// Tries tmux pane ID first, falls back to timestamp
    50→func getSessionID() string {
    51→	// Try to get tmux pane ID
    52→	cmd := exec.Command("tmux", "display-message", "-p", "#D")
    53→	if output, err := cmd.Output(); err == nil {
    54→		paneID := strings.TrimSpace(string(output))
    55→		if paneID != "" {
    56→			return paneID
    57→		}
    58→	}
    59→
    60→	// Fallback to timestamp
    61→	return time.Now().Format("2006-01-02-150405")
    62→}
    63→
    64→// newSession creates a new session
    65→func newSession(id string, rootPath string) *Session {
    66→	return &Session{
    67→		ID:        id,
    68→		RootPath:  rootPath,
    69→		StartTime: time.Now(),
    70→		Changed:   make(map[string]bool),
    71→	}
    72→}
    73→
    74→// sessionExists checks if a session file exists
    75→func sessionExists(sessionID string) bool {
    76→	sessionPath := filepath.Join(getSessionDir(), sessionID+".json")
    77→	_, err := os.Stat(sessionPath)
    78→	return err == nil
    79→}
    80→
    81→// loadSession loads a session from disk
    82→func loadSession(sessionID string) (*Session, error) {
    83→	sessionPath := filepath.Join(getSessionDir(), sessionID+".json")
    84→
    85→	data, err := os.ReadFile(sessionPath)
    86→	if err != nil {
    87→		return nil, err
    88→	}
    89→
    90→	var session Session
    91→	if err := json.Unmarshal(data, &session); err != nil {
    92→		return nil, err
    93→	}
    94→
    95→	return &session, nil
    96→}
    97→
    98→// saveSession saves a session to disk
    99→func saveSession(session *Session) error {
   100→	sessionPath := filepath.Join(getSessionDir(), session.ID+".json")
   101→
   102→	data, err := json.MarshalIndent(session, "", "  ")
   103→	if err != nil {
   104→		return err
   105→	}
   106→
   107→	return os.WriteFile(sessionPath, data, 0644)
   108→}
   109→
   110→// getFileSizeColor returns color based on file line count
   111→func getFileSizeColor(filePath string) string {
   112→	data, err := os.ReadFile(filePath)
   113→	if err != nil {
   114→		panic("failed to read file for size coloring: " + err.Error())
   115→	}
   116→
   117→	lines := strings.Count(string(data), "\n")
   118→
   119→	switch {
   120→	case lines < 50:
   121→		return "42" // green
   122→	case lines < 100:
   123→		return "148" // yellow-green
   124→	case lines < 150:
   125→		return "226" // yellow
   126→	case lines < 200:
   127→		return "214" // orange
   128→	default:
   129→		return "196" // red
   130→	}
   131→}
   132→

1→package main
     2→
     3→import (
     4→	"encoding/json"
     5→	"fmt"
     6→	"os/exec"
     7→	"strings"
     8→)
     9→
    10→// saveSessionSkate saves session to Skate database
    11→func saveSessionSkate(session *Session) error {
    12→	data, err := json.Marshal(session)
    13→	if err != nil {
    14→		return err
    15→	}
    16→
    17→	key := fmt.Sprintf("session@vinw-%s", session.ID)
    18→	cmd := exec.Command("skate", "set", key, string(data))
    19→	return cmd.Run()
    20→}
    21→
    22→// loadSessionSkate loads session from Skate database
    23→// Returns nil if session doesn't exist (not an error)
    24→func loadSessionSkate(sessionID string) (*Session, error) {
    25→	key := fmt.Sprintf("session@vinw-%s", sessionID)
    26→	cmd := exec.Command("skate", "get", key)
    27→	output, err := cmd.Output()
    28→	if err != nil {
    29→		// Session doesn't exist
    30→		return nil, nil
    31→	}
    32→
    33→	var session Session
    34→	if err := json.Unmarshal(output, &session); err != nil {
    35→		return nil, err
    36→	}
    37→
    38→	return &session, nil
    39→}
    40→
    41→// sessionExistsSkate checks if a session exists in Skate
    42→func sessionExistsSkate(sessionID string) bool {
    43→	key := fmt.Sprintf("session@vinw-%s", sessionID)
    44→	cmd := exec.Command("skate", "get", key)
    45→	return cmd.Run() == nil
    46→}
    47→
    48→// deleteSessionSkate deletes a session from Skate
    49→func deleteSessionSkate(sessionID string) error {
    50→	key := fmt.Sprintf("session@vinw-%s", sessionID)
    51→	cmd := exec.Command("skate", "delete", key)
    52→	return cmd.Run()
    53→}
    54→
    55→// listSessionsSkate lists all vinw sessions in Skate
    56→func listSessionsSkate() ([]string, error) {
    57→	// List all databases
    58→	cmd := exec.Command("skate", "list-dbs")
    59→	output, err := cmd.Output()
    60→	if err != nil {
    61→		return nil, err
    62→	}
    63→
    64→	lines := strings.Split(string(output), "\n")
    65→	var sessions []string
    66→
    67→	for _, line := range lines {
    68→		line = strings.TrimSpace(line)
    69→		// Look for databases like "@vinw-{sessionID}"
    70→		if strings.HasPrefix(line, "@vinw-") {
    71→			// Extract session ID
    72→			sessionID := strings.TrimPrefix(line, "@vinw-")
    73→			if sessionID != "" {
    74→				sessions = append(sessions, sessionID)
    75→			}
    76→		}
    77→	}
    78→
    79→	return sessions, nil
    80→}
    81→

## ✨ New Visual Design

**File Size Indicators** (appears before each filename):
- `●` Green dot - Small files (< 50 lines)

- `◎` Yellow double circle - Medium (100-150 lines)

- `◆` Red filled diamond - Very large (200+ lines)

- Each file has a colorful size indicator character at the beginning
- Modified files still show the dark teal `✱` star at the end
- Much more subtle and elegant than color-changing filenames

The design now follows the Bubble Tea aesthetic - minimal, clean text with small pops of color through meaningful indicators. The app has been rebuilt and is ready to run!

content.text: Now let's build and test the app:

Perfect! I've transformed the app into a minimal GitHub-focused tool. Here's what's been done:

## ✅ Changes Completed

### 1. **Removed Session/Skate Code**
- Moved `session.go`, `session_test.go`, `skate_session.go`, `skate_session_test.go` to `unused/` directory
- Removed all session tracking from the main app

### 2. **Added GitHub Integration**
- Created `github.go` with minimal GitHub CLI integration
- On first run, checks if in git repo
- If not, prompts to create a GitHub repo with name/description
- Uses `gh` CLI to create repo and push initial commit

### 3. **Git Diff Line Tracking**
- Replaced file modification tracking with `git diff --numstat`
- Shows `(+X)` in green next to files with uncommitted changes
- Just like GitHub's UI!

### 4. **Simplified UI**
- Removed all color-changing filenames
- Clean gray filenames with green `(+X)` indicators for changes
- Removed session info from header/footer
- Minimal footer: just "↑/↓: scroll | q: quit"

### 5. **Code is Minimal**
- Removed all unused features
- Clean, simple codebase focused on one thing
- `.git` directory is automatically hidden

## How It Works Now

1. Run `./vinw` in any directory
2. If not a git repo, it prompts to create a GitHub repo
3. Shows file tree with `(+X)` for files with uncommitted changes
4. Updates every 5 seconds to catch new changes

The code is now extremely minimal and focused solely on showing git changes in a clean tree view!

content.text:
Perfect! Now we have a clean solution that uses Skate to track whether we've already asked about creating a GitHub repo for each directory. Here's how it works:

## 🎯 How First Run Tracking Works

1. **Skate Storage**: Uses Skate to store a key like `vinw-repo-/absolute/path/to/dir` 
2. **First Run Detection**: When you run vinw in a directory:
   - Checks if it's already a git repo → skip prompt
   - Checks Skate if we've asked before → skip prompt
   - Otherwise → show welcome message and ask to create repo

3. **User Flow**:
   - First run in new directory → "Welcome to Vinw! Create GitHub repository? (y/n)"
   - If user says 'n' → marks directory in Skate, never asks again
   - If user says 'y' → creates repo, marks in Skate
   - Subsequent runs → no prompts, just shows the tree

## 📁 Code Organization

- **`github.go`**: Handles repo creation and git diff tracking
- **`skate.go`**: Minimal Skate integration just for tracking repos
- **`main.go`**: Clean, minimal main loop
- **`unused/`**: Old session tracking code (can delete if not needed)

The app now properly tracks first run per directory using Skate, keeping the code minimal while providing a smooth user experience!

<tool_use_error>String to replace not found in file.
String: // initGitHub initializes GitHub repo on first run
func initGitHub(path string) error {
	// Check if already in a git repo
	if isInGitRepo() {
		return nil
	}

	// Check if we've already been asked about this directory
	if hasCreatedRepo(path) {
		return nil
	}

	// Check if GitHub CLI is available
	if !hasGitHubCLI() {
		return fmt.Errorf("GitHub CLI not available - run 'gh auth login' to set up")
	}

	account := getGitHubAccount()
	if account == "" {
		return fmt.Errorf("could not determine GitHub account")
	}

	fmt.Printf("\n🚀 Welcome to Vinw!\n")
	fmt.Printf("GitHub account: %s\n", account)
	fmt.Printf("Directory: %s\n\n", path)
	fmt.Print("Create GitHub repository? (y/n): ")

	var response string
	fmt.Scanln(&response)

	if response != "y" && response != "Y" {
		// Mark as asked so we don't prompt again
		markRepoCreated(path)
		return nil
	}

	fmt.Print("Repository name: ")
	var repoName string
	fmt.Scanln(&repoName)

	if repoName == "" {
		markRepoCreated(path)
		return fmt.Errorf("no repository name provided")
	}

	fmt.Print("Description (optional): ")
	var description string
	fmt.Scanln(&description)

	fmt.Print("Public or private? (public/PRIVATE): ")
	var visibility string
	fmt.Scanln(&visibility)

	isPublic := visibility == "public"

	// Initialize git repo
	exec.Command("git", "init").Run()

	// Create GitHub repo
	args := []string{"repo", "create", repoName}
	if isPublic {
		args = append(args, "--public")
	} else {
		args = append(args, "--private")
	}
	if description != "" {
		args = append(args, "--description", description)
	}
	args = append(args, "--source", ".")

	cmd = exec.Command("gh", args...)
	if err := cmd.Run(); err != nil {
		return fmt.Errorf("failed to create repository: %v", err)
	}

	// Make initial commit
	exec.Command("git", "add", ".").Run()
	exec.Command("git", "commit", "-m", "Initial commit").Run()
	exec.Command("git", "push", "-u", "origin", "main").Run()

	// Mark as created
	markRepoCreated(path)

	fmt.Println("\n✅ Repository created successfully!")
	return nil
}</tool_use_error>

content.text:
Perfect! Now the logic is correct:

## 🎯 How It Works Now

1. **Every Run**: Checks if current directory is in a git repo
   - **Has git repo** → Shows tree with `(+X)` for changed files
   - **No git repo** → Offers to create one (unless previously declined)

2. **User Choices Are Remembered**:
   - If user says **'n'** → Marks directory as "declined" in Skate, won't ask again
   - If user says **'y'** → Creates repo, no need to track (now has git!)
   - If user later runs `git init` manually → Will detect git repo and show changes

3. **Skate Usage** (minimal):
   - Only stores `vinw-declined-{path}` for directories where user said 'no'
   - Clears this flag if repo is successfully created
   - No "first run" tracking - just tracks user's choice

## 📊 The Flow

```
Run vinw → Is git repo? 
  ├─ YES → Show tree with (+X) changes
  └─ NO → Previously declined?
      ├─ YES → Show tree without changes
      └─ NO → Ask to create repo
          ├─ User says YES → Create repo → Show with changes
          └─ User says NO → Mark declined → Show without changes
```

This way it always tracks changes when there's a git repo, and only prompts once per directory if there isn't one!

String: // initGitHub checks for git repo and offers to create one if needed
func initGitHub(path string) error {
	// Check if already in a git repo
	if isInGitRepo() {
		// Already have git, no need to create
		return nil
	}

	// Check if user previously declined for this directory
	if hasDeclinedRepo(path) {
		// User said no before, don't ask again
		return nil
	}

	// Check if GitHub CLI is available
	if !hasGitHubCLI() {
		// No GitHub CLI, can't create repo
		fmt.Println("GitHub CLI not found. Install with: brew install gh && gh auth login")
		return nil
	}

	account := getGitHubAccount()
	if account == "" {
		fmt.Println("Not logged into GitHub. Run: gh auth login")
		return nil
	}

	fmt.Printf("\n📁 No git repository detected\n")
	fmt.Printf("GitHub account: %s\n", account)
	fmt.Printf("Directory: %s\n\n", path)
	fmt.Print("Create GitHub repository to track changes? (y/n): ")

	var response string
	fmt.Scanln(&response)

	if response != "y" && response != "Y" {
		// Remember they declined so we don't ask every time
		markRepoDeclined(path)
		fmt.Println("Continuing without git tracking. Run 'git init' manually to enable change tracking.")
		return nil
	}

	fmt.Print("Repository name: ")
	var repoName string
	fmt.Scanln(&repoName)

	if repoName == "" {
		markRepoDeclined(path)
		return fmt.Errorf("no repository name provided")
	}

	fmt.Print("Description (optional): ")
	var description string
	fmt.Scanln(&description)

	fmt.Print("Public or private? (public/PRIVATE): ")
	var visibility string
	fmt.Scanln(&visibility)

	isPublic := visibility == "public"

	// Initialize git repo
	exec.Command("git", "init").Run()

	// Create GitHub repo
	args := []string{"repo", "create", repoName}
	if isPublic {
		args = append(args, "--public")
	} else {
		args = append(args, "--private")
	}
	if description != "" {
		args = append(args, "--description", description)
	}
	args = append(args, "--source", ".")

	cmd = exec.Command("gh", args...)
	if err := cmd.Run(); err != nil {
		return fmt.Errorf("failed to create repository: %v", err)
	}

	// Make initial commit
	exec.Command("git", "add", ".").Run()
	exec.Command("git", "commit", "-m", "Initial commit").Run()
	exec.Command("git", "push", "-u", "origin", "main").Run()

	// No need to mark as created - we have a git repo now!
	// Clear any previous decline
	clearRepoDeclined(path)

	fmt.Println("\n✅ Repository created successfully!")
	return nil
}</tool_use_error>

content.text:
Perfect! Now vinw has a full Bubble Tea interface for GitHub setup. Here's what it does:

## 🎯 Features

### Multiple Account Support
- Detects all GitHub accounts including organizations
- Shows a selection menu if you have multiple accounts
- Auto-selects if you only have one account

### Interactive Repo Creation Flow
1. **Account Selection** (if multiple)
   - Use ↑/↓ to select account
   - Press Enter to confirm

2. **Confirm Creation**
   - Shows directory and selected account
   - Press 'y' to create, 'n' to decline

3. **Repository Name**
   - Enter your repo name
   - Press Enter to continue

4. **Description** (optional)
   - Add a description or leave blank
   - Press Enter to continue

5. **Visibility**
   - Press 'p' for public
   - Press Enter for private (default)

### Clean Bubble Tea UI
- Beautiful styled prompts
- Navigation hints at each step
- Escape key to go back
- All using Bubble Tea components

### Smart Behavior
- Only prompts once per directory (uses Skate to remember)
- Skips prompt if already in git repo
- Works with git diff to show `(+X)` for changed files

Now when you run `./vinw` in a non-git directory, you'll get a beautiful interactive prompt to create a GitHub repo with proper account selection!

content.text:
Great! I've fixed the hanging issue. The changes include:

## 🔧 Fixes Applied

1. **Async Repo Creation**: The `createRepo` function now returns a `tea.Cmd` that runs asynchronously and sends a `repoCreatedMsg` when complete

2. **Proper Message Handling**: Added a `repoCreatedMsg` type that the Update method handles to know when creation is done

3. **Organization Support**: When creating repos for organizations, it properly prefixes the repo name with `org/repo-name`

4. **Better Error Handling**: Shows detailed error messages if repo creation fails

5. **Simplified Push**: Uses `--push` flag with `gh repo create` instead of separate push command

## How It Works Now

1. When you select visibility and confirm, it triggers `createRepo()` as a command
2. The UI shows "Creating Repository..." while it works
3. Git operations run in the background
4. When done, it sends a message back to update the UI
5. Shows success or error message and quits

The app should no longer hang when creating repos. Try running `./vinw` in a non-git directory now!

input.description: Build vinw with fixed commit order

content.text:
Fixed! The issue was that `--push` flag requires commits to exist before creating the repo. Now the order is:

1. `git init` - Initialize repository
2. `git add .` - Stage files (if any)
3. `git commit -m "Initial commit"` - Make initial commit
   - If no files, uses `--allow-empty` to create an empty commit
4. `gh repo create --push` - Create repo and push the commit

This ensures there's always at least one commit before trying to push. Try running `./vinw` again in a non-git directory!

content.text:
Yes, exactly! The logic in `initGitHub` checks for an existing git repo first:

```go
// Check if already in a git repo
if isInGitRepo() {
    // Already have git, no need to create
    return nil
}
```

So the flow is:

1. **Has Git Repo** → Skips all prompts, shows tree with `(+X)` for changed files
2. **No Git Repo** → Offers to create one (unless previously declined)

Once a repo exists (either already there or newly created), vinw will:
- Show the file tree
- Display `(+X)` next to files with uncommitted changes
- Update every 5 seconds to catch new changes
- Never prompt about GitHub again for that directory

So yes, if you run vinw in an existing git repo, it just picks up the status and shows changes - no prompts, just the tree view with git diff tracking!

content.thinking:
Now I have a clear understanding of the performance issues:

1. **Every 5 seconds**, the app:
   - Rebuilds the entire tree from scratch
   - Calls `git diff --numstat HEAD -- <file>` for EVERY SINGLE FILE
   - Converts the entire tree to a string
   - Replaces the entire viewport content

For a large repo with hundreds or thousands of files, this means hundreds/thousands of git processes spawned every 5 seconds!

The scrolling gets stuck because when the viewport content is being replaced during a tick update, it interrupts the smooth scrolling.

Here's my plan to fix this WITHOUT disrupting the working code:

## Performance Optimization Plan

### 1. **Cache Git Diff Results**
   - Store git diff results in a map
   - Only update when files actually change (use file mod time)
   - Run a single `git diff --numstat HEAD` for all files at once instead of per-file

### 2. **Optimize Git Diff Calls**
   - Replace individual `git diff` calls per file with a single batch call
   - Parse the output once and cache the results
   - This reduces git calls from N files to 1 call

### 3. **Smart Tree Updates**
   - Only rebuild the tree if files have actually changed
   - Keep track of last modification times
   - Don't replace viewport content if nothing changed

### 4. **Viewport Optimization**
   - Only call SetContent when content actually changes
   - Store a hash of the content to detect changes
   - This prevents interrupting scrolling

### 5. **Reduce Update Frequency for Large Repos**
   - Detect repo size
   - Use longer tick intervals for larger repos
   - Or implement smart dirty checking

The key changes will be:
- Create a `gitDiffCache` map to store results
- Modify `getGitDiffLines` to use batch processing
- Add change detection before updating viewport
 
I'll preserve the existing architecture while implementing these optimizations. The goal is to maintain the current UI structure and interaction model completely untouched. This means carefully layering the performance improvements without altering the fundamental design of the application's tree rendering and viewport management.

By focusing on caching, minimizing redundant operations, and smart change detection, I can dramatically reduce computational overhead without introducing any structural changes to the existing code. The UI will remain pixel-perfect and responsive, just with significantly improved backend efficiency.

content.text:
Based on my analysis of the code and Bubble Tea examples, I've identified the performance bottlenecks in the scrolling. Here's my plan to fix the issues WITHOUT disrupting the working code:

## Performance Issues Identified

1. **Excessive Git Calls**: Every 5 seconds, the app calls `git diff` for EVERY file individually (hundreds/thousands of processes for large repos)
2. **Complete Tree Rebuilds**: The entire tree is rebuilt from scratch every tick
3. **Viewport Content Replacement**: The entire viewport content is replaced even when nothing changes, interrupting smooth scrolling

input.plan:
## Scrolling Performance Optimization Plan

### 1. **Batch Git Diff Operations**
- Replace individual `git diff` calls per file with ONE batch call
- Create `getAllGitDiffs()` function that runs `git diff --numstat HEAD` once
- Returns a map[filepath]→lines for all changed files
- Reduces git subprocess calls from N to 1

### 2. **Add Git Diff Caching**
- Store git diff results in model struct as `diffCache map[string]int`
- Update cache only when needed (every tick)
- Pass cache to buildTreeRecursive to avoid repeated lookups

### 3. **Smart Viewport Updates**
- Store previous tree content hash
- Only call `SetContent()` if content actually changed
- This prevents interrupting smooth scrolling

### 4. **Optimize Tree Building**
- Pass diffCache through recursive calls
- Remove per-file git diff calls from tree building
- Keep existing tree structure and rendering

### 5. **Add Performance Monitoring** (optional)
- Track time taken for git operations
- Adjust tick frequency based on repo size

### Files to Modify:
1. **main.go**: Add diffCache to model, optimize tickMsg handler
2. **github.go**: Add batch git diff function
3. No changes to UI, tree structure, or working features

The result will be:
- Smooth scrolling even in large repos
- Reduced CPU usage (1 git call vs hundreds)
- No visual or functional changes to the app

Perfect! I've successfully optimized the scrolling performance without disrupting any working code. Here's what was done:

## ✅ Performance Optimizations Completed

### 1. **Batch Git Operations** 
- Added `getAllGitDiffs()` function that makes ONE `git diff --numstat HEAD` call
- Previously: Called `git diff` for EVERY file (hundreds/thousands of processes)
- Now: Single git process returns all changed files at once

### 2. **Caching System**
- Added `diffCache` map to model to store git diff results
- Cache is updated once per tick with batch operation
- Tree building uses cached values instead of spawning new processes

### 3. **Smart Viewport Updates**
- Added `lastContent` tracking to detect actual changes
- Only calls `SetContent()` when tree content actually changes
- Prevents interrupting smooth scrolling during unchanged ticks

### 4. **Zero Breaking Changes**
- All existing functionality preserved
- UI remains exactly the same
- Git diff indicators still show `(+X)` for changed files
- Tree structure unchanged

## Performance Impact

For a repository with 500 files:
- **Before**: 500 git processes every 5 seconds
- **After**: 1 git process every 5 seconds
- **Reduction**: 99.8% fewer subprocess calls

The scrolling should now be buttery smooth even in large repositories, as the viewport content isn't being replaced unless there are actual changes to display!

input.description: Build vinw with broken remote detection

content.text:
Perfect! I've added comprehensive handling for the case where a local git repo exists but the remote has been deleted. Here's what the app now does:

## 🔧 Broken Remote Detection & Recovery

### Detection Flow:
1. **Checks if in git repo** → Yes
2. **Checks if has remote** → Yes
3. **Checks if remote exists** → No (404, deleted, etc.)
4. **Result**: Offers to create a new GitHub repo to replace the broken remote

### What Happens:
- **Detects broken remote**: Uses `git ls-remote origin HEAD` to check if remote is accessible
- **Shows warning**: "⚠️ Remote repository not accessible" with the old URL
- **Offers to fix**: Prompts to create a new GitHub repo to replace the missing remote
- **Updates remote URL**: After creating new repo, updates the git remote URL
- **Pushes existing commits**: Preserves all your existing work and history

### Key Features:
- **Clears decline status** when remote is broken (so it asks again)
- **Preserves existing commits** - doesn't reinitialize the repo
- **Updates remote URL** automatically after creating new repo
- **Handles both main and master branches** when pushing

### User Experience:
1. If remote repo was deleted on GitHub, vinw detects this
2. Shows clear message about the problem
3. Offers to create a replacement repo
4. Handles everything automatically - creates repo, updates URL, pushes commits

This ensures users never lose work if they accidentally delete a GitHub repo - they can easily recreate it with all their local commits intact!

content.text:
Perfect! I've added comprehensive gitignore support to vinw. Here's what's been implemented:

## 🚫 GitIgnore Features

### New Functionality:
1. **`.gitignore` File Created** - Ignores `logs/` directory and common files
2. **GitIgnore Parser** - Reads and parses `.gitignore` patterns
3. **Toggle Feature** - Press `i` to toggle gitignore ON/OFF
4. **Visual Indicator** - Footer shows `gitignore [ON]` or `gitignore [OFF]`
5. **Respects Patterns** - File tree hides ignored files when ON

### Pattern Support:
- Directory patterns (e.g., `logs/`, `vendor/`)
- Wildcard patterns (e.g., `*.log`, `*.exe`)
- Specific files (e.g., `.DS_Store`)
- Comments and empty lines in `.gitignore`
- Always ignores `.git` directory regardless of toggle

### User Controls:
- **Default**: gitignore is ON (respects `.gitignore`)
- **Press 'i'**: Toggle gitignore ON/OFF
- **When OFF**: Shows all files including ignored ones
- **When ON**: Hides files matching `.gitignore` patterns

### Implementation Details:
- Efficient pattern matching without external dependencies
- Real-time toggle without restarting the app
- Works with existing git diff tracking
- Ignored files won't show changes (as expected in git)

The `logs/` directory is now properly ignored by default, and users can toggle the gitignore feature on and off to see all files when needed!

content.text:
Perfect! Now when you run `./vinw` from the app directory, it will:

1. Load the `.gitignore` file from app/
2. By default, `gitignore [ON]` - the `unused/` directory will be hidden
3. Press `i` to toggle to `gitignore [OFF]` - the `unused/` directory will appear
4. Press `i` again to toggle back to `gitignore [ON]` - `unused/` disappears

The app folder now has a .gitignore that ignores:
- `unused/` directory (where the old session files are)
- `logs/` directory  
- Test and temporary files
- Binary files

Try running `./vinw app` and pressing 'i' to see the `unused/` folder appear and disappear!
